item.title: DIY 3: Variations and thoughts
item.description:
Here I cover variations I have htought about already for design and construction.

I also make sure to go over all the considerations about why things work and why things don't.
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: DIY 1: Buy the materials with me! [VIDEO]
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: DIY 1: Buying the materials
item.description:
This post lists the EXACT materials I use and where to buy them.

IMPORTANT - I do not explain WHY to use these materials and why others do not work in this post. Please refer to the youtube video or this post: DIY: Variations

Like video? Walk through the store with me in this video: A trip to Joann Fabrics

REQUIRED

The MOST important things are the fabric and elastic. These must not be substituted.

Item Quantity Price Name Store item#
Fabric 1 yard $14.99 Sew Classics Spandex Knit Fabric JoAnn Fabrics XPRD892872
Waist Band Elastic 1 pkg $16.99 Dritz 1" Foldover Elastic Black 7 Yards Joann Fabrics 13059589
Comfort Elastic 1 pkg $2.99 Prym Dritz Non-Roll Knit Elastic White Joann Fabrics 575134
Ring and Sliders 1 pkg $2.99 Dritz 0.38" Lingerie Strap Slides/Rings 3 Sets Joann Fabrics 5047261
Hook and Eye 1 pkg $3.99 Dritz Hooks & Eyes Size 1 14/Pkg-Nickel Joann Fabrics 1027853
Scissors 1 pair $8.49 Westcott 8" Ultra Smooth Titanium Scissors-Bent Joann Fabrics 9816166
Hand Sewing needle and thread 1 kit $5.49 CVS Singer Sewing Kit CVS
Total without tax $55.93

A LOT I KNOW. However, with all this, you will be able to make a LOT of them. 1 yard of fabric will give you approziametly 20 or more. The wasit band elastic will give you about 3-5. The comfort elastic will give you about 10-15. The hook and eyes will give you plenty.

To make it cheaper:

  1. Buy from the remnants section! Only buy what you need for a couple to try and fail on before committing to a whole yard
  2. Maybe you can buy the waist band elastic by the yard so only buy your hips measurement + 6 inches rounded up to the nearest yard.
  3. If you already have a pair of scissors Don't buy them!
  4. This could reduce your starting cost to around $30.

Optional items to make it easier

Item Quantity Price Name Store item#
Rotary cutter 1 $10.99 Fiskars Titanium Comfort Stick Rotary Cutter 45mm Joann Fabrics 10805208
Cutting Board 1 $9.99 Olfa Cutting Mat 12x18"-Pink Joann Fabrics 16303299
Total without tax $20.98

These two items help you make MUCH cleaner cuts on the fabric. Which is very helpful.

You of course can use any old cutting board you might already have.

Home materials you might already have

Item Options
Fabric Old Spandex Swimsuit might do but be timid. Likely need at least 5"x20" of it.
Waist Band Elastic I would not trust at-home elastics for this
Comfort Elastic I would not trust at-home elastics for this
Ring and Sliders maybe a bar, but these sliders and rings tend to be too small
Hook and Eye Old bra is great for these
Scissors You likely have some that will do, but ideally the sharper the better
Hand Sewing needle and thread Lots of us have something like this lying around.
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: DIY 2: Making it [VIDEO]
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: DIY 4: Thoughts for the Future
item.description:
This is specifically about the future of the product. 1. What it needs 2. How to get it there

Known Bugs

  • Bunching in back can cause pinching

this coudl be solved by a different cut of the fabric. Somethign that narrows as it goes back might not bunch the same way. A more experienced garment designer might easily come up with a solution.

  • It is not perfect in water

Fabric changes might help deal with swimming. There is something called Fabrifoam which might do okay. Also some kind of rubber might help here too.

  • The waist band sometimes slips down

This could be solved by making the elastic a T shape. Ideall this is resolved with a temporary/removable feature. However triyng to get it together like that has been difficult. Another option is to make the waist band out of two elastics. One is the small loop which goes in the fabric and up the butt. The other loops through the elastic and goes around the front. This does two things, it makes the removeable waist band cleaner (as the other elastic will sit in the butt) and thus wearable for multiple days. It also means there is a permanent elastic attached to the panel.

Improvement ideas

Wasit band needs updating. The elastic I use now is merely the best I have found so far. Ideally it is thinner but just as strong, and maybe even more comfortable. However if you use a different elastic for the butt cheeks, the comfort of the elastic is less important.

Better construction method for placement of eyes on panel. Currently my methods are limited to my knoweldge. The placement of the eye does seem to effect the visual of it as well as the function. Placing the eye right on the edge does seem to lessen the effect of the comfort band some. But placing it farther in makes it a bit more bulky to look at. Therefore, updating the shape and style of the comfort band alpongside this may make a big difference.

I have long thought to put an elastic down the middle of the panel. This extra elastic may smooth out the look. IF the fabric is too elastic, the shaft of the penis can often cause it to buldge in that place, however an elastic there might help smooth it out. I have never gotten this to work well.

Side seams may help the durability. By running a seam down the side of the panel it may last longer. But still leave a channel open for the elastic. IF you update to use 2 elastics, this is acutally easier. But if still only one, you have to thread a smaller hole every time in the future.

2 different fabrics may also provide some benefits. One fabric for the oputside one for the inside. The inside one could be used for comfort and the outside for proper tensioning. Or the inside could be specialized for athletics, water, or something else. Or the outside one could be used for aesthetics and the inside for structure. The biggest limiting factor here is stretch. The least stretchy fabric will win out in terms of tension, which may be hard with lace. You could also choose a different fabric for the inside of the comfort band but nowhere else. This could be used to try and create more stability in the tuck. AS, this is the palce where it is most liekly to slip first.

Moving Foward

  1. Measurement Guide MUST be finished

This is the worst part. How to get the BARE MINIMUM of measurements so you can get the perfect fit. Ideally without being invasisve. This has been so difficult and the entire reason I cannot make good progress.

  1. Prototype into heaven

Keep going until a more solid deisng is found. And create different models to capture different needs if one model won't do it all

  1. Seek out manufacturuers

  2. Make some
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: The importance of proper measurements
item.description:
So, in my years on HRT now, I have gone up and down on my doses A LOT, and consequently, my junk has changed many times... 🤐

Point is, I have not worn one of my gaffs in a while for a couple reasons. I tried a couple on in the last few days and they do not fit as well before.

Therefore, it truly is important for me to have a way to measure how large your genitals are while flaccid in some way.

And this, is the whole reason I have struggled to finish this project. How the heck do you get the right measurements AND explain how to get them succinctly?

This is not over, just persistantly delayed. Sigh.
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: A failed glue experiment: Tear Mender
item.description:
I tried using a glue called Tear Mender in attempt to glue the elastic to the fabric before sewing it. Mistake.

It did not work the way I hoped. I seeped deep into the fabric and wouldn't set. Then it pilled and didn't look good. So, not this kind of glue.

I know, exciting post...

I wish I had more help.
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: Experiment using snaps instead of hook and eyes for the elastic
item.description:
Today, a friend had the materials for putting snaps on stuff so I tried making a gaff with snaps!

I was surprised. It went well, looked good, and functioned fine. For at least two hours of sitting and standing everything was fine.

I am definitely going to get some people to try this out. Especially those who have tried the hook and eye style already.
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: Liner Gaff: Intro video
item.description: Look what I finished! The Intro Video!!!
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: New Construction Method Experiment
item.description:
So I had an epiphany about how to construct the gaff while making one for a new person. So I thought I'd try it out. I am impressed and can't wait to keep experimenting with this to prove it's a solid construction method.

I'm looking for a couple things:

  • Is is durable?
  • Does it provide the same level of tucking quality?
  • Does it take less time to construct?

Very quickly I can answer, it takes WAY less time to make. It took 55 minutes for me to make one of these panels. I went from 6 stitches to 1 stitch. Wow.

I am hopeful that the placement of the eye all the way up in the corner is a benefit, although that needs to be tested a bunch.

It appears the tuck is fine as well. However I am trying out new materials and it looks like I need to adjust my sizing for these other materials so they function perfectly.

More experiments with these fabrics coming soon!
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: First Gaff for another person in a while
item.description:
I met up with a cool girl I met online for a second time today. This time to make a gaff for her and see what happened.

OMG!!! DUDE! THIS THING IS SO PERFECT!
I'm seriously shocked right now. This is like the tightest and most comfortable tuck I've ever had!
Thank you so much!!!!!
Seriously!!!

Phew. It took me a lot longer tha normal to make it so I wasn't there to get initial reactions. But I am very happy to have made another person this happy.
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: Pride in progress on the Liner Gaff
item.description:
I am proud of all I have done.

  • I explored and experimented
  • I faced my shame regarding tucking
  • I kept working at it even when I was disheartened
  • I pushed myself to share it with people, regardless of how scary that was
  • I created a website to show people
  • I am proud of how well this functions
  • and how painless it is compared to its competitors

I so easily fall into shame and fear when I want to tell people about my gaff. It's not perfect. The elastic is too thick right now. The hooks still often create tiny bumps because I haven't quite figured out the perfect placement. The back of the panel still bunches up and can sometimes pinch. I haven't found a way to resolve that yet.

But what I have done is remarkable, note worthy and worth sharing. One day I'll stop having to fight myself at all and purely believe it.

Thank you for letting me share what I have to be proud of.
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra

item.title: Introducing: The Liner Gaff
item.description:
The Liner Gaff is a personal project I have been working on for a few years now to create a gaff that fits the needs of those who tuck daily/regularly.

After trying nearly every kind of commercial option and do it yourself option, I was disenchanted. These options were expensive, cheap, bulky, ugly, or painful. So I began experimenting.

I came up with a list of lofty features and kept aiming for them. As of today, I feel I have met these features more so than nearly all other gaff options out there. I hope by sharing this with the world it can get even closer to meeting those goals.

I struggle a lot with the balance of authenticity and veneer. I truly believe in the progress I have made with this gaff design and the improvements yet to come. However this ethical quandary of authenticity versus propaganda keeps my stomach churning. Do I sell? or undersell? How do I create realness?

After all this time, energy, and experimenting. As I grow out of shame, fear, and pain, I am ready to share my project with the world. I am so proud of this.

What to Expect

I am very happy to have this website up, and cannot wait to keep updating everyone with the progress I am making.

I want as much feedback as I can get so I can make something that valuable for all my siblings.

You'll also see:

  • Posts about theory and goals
  • Updates about materials/design
  • Compelling feedback from people
  • Milestones
  • In person visits with people who try it

I am preparing to head south for a couple months very soon. I will be on the road, and hopefully meeting up with as many people as possible, making gaffs.
item.dc:creator: Luna Umbra
